Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 02:38PM stagefree wrote: Dear Julie, I second Janis on this. I recently started visiting a psychiatrist for my anxiety related sleeping problems. I had been prescribed Xanax & Lexapro at dx, but it turned out that I was taking them wrong-though the dose was right. Doc explained that to help the anxiety building up in my system resolve, I needed to have the meds act 24/7. So, instead of increasing the doses (which I thought was the only way to solve the problem), he simply divided them to be taken at specific times of the day. And it WORKED! I do still wake up a couple of times during the night due to the Tamoxifen hotflashes, but can go back to sleep easier than before. And wake up feeling relaxed & rested. I strongly suggest you check this out with your doc.Â  I do have some tough moments every now & then, but at least get some regular quality sleep every day. Oh and I can say time flies playing scrabble on ipad :) Love & hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 12:53AM - edited Mar 26, 2015 12:55AM by stagefree My dearest Chris, First & foremost all toxic people OUT !!! And I mean it, you know me well by now. We can't choose our family members, please bear this mind. You are not stuck with any of them once you have your OWN family. Ideally, it would be best to have good relations with everyone, but not worth fighting for an already lost battle. People can be mean, bad and it's best to avoid them. I'm sure you already know all I've written so far.. Yet sometimes one needs to hear / read in our case from someone else. Would you rather force yourself into a fake relation with the ones who only keep hurting you or spare your most precious time left with the cutest ever grandchild? Stress is not good in our case, we are to just become as SELFISH as we can for the sake of our loved ones. They deserve to spend as much time as we can possibly have. I believe that the people who cause more struggle to the ill only ruin their own karma eventually. And do trust the fairness of the Universe. You don't have to prove anyone anything as long as you are confident with the truth. And my very sensitive & emotional friend, I know you and love you. As many other friends in your life, all of whom you had the luxury to choose. Quite often, friends become closer than many members of the family. Finally, boo to all who made my sweet Chis cry over such bullshit! Huge hugs & love Ebru

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 08:10AM stagefree wrote: hi Guess having dealt with cancer in different for s for more than 3 decades in the family, 2 of which have been mine.. I get you..Â  Blamed, cursed at, wanted to leave everyone & everything at different points of my life.. Now at 39 (with MBC the past 3 years) I am at peace sort of Â with them all. But more importantly with myself. This is MY reality, which I expect none of my loved ones to ever undestand or accept. I am alone in this. So just settled my relation with them cancerfree, love them and cherish their existence. Docs are better in understanding, yet they speak based on proof. Not self experience. I take all medsociety can offer and accept they cannot fill in the blanks left still. BCO literally kept me awake and motivated to learn, share & support (give and take) in so many dark times. So please stay here. Helps so much.Â  Well shit happens. To some it's more frequent. Since can't change it, leaving things to the flow is best. You get treatment, support, live your daily life best as possible and it ends someday. To us it is a horrifying reality with each breath.. Not easy.Â  My first response upon dx was "wish I didnnt have a kid" we all are different :) that's for sure We make our vows at marriage but so few really mean it in real sense or understand what we are taking on as responsibility. Why all the fuss? Your DH did promise to be by your side no matter what Ä± am sure. Did the vows included promise of "giving" children to him I wonder? If so, you may feel guilt ;)Â  Hey sister welcome on board. You are not alone. One day at a time. No need to persuade anyone what you want or not want to do. Your life, your decisions. You know what's best for you.Â  Always the best & hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 10:05AM stagefree wrote: I admit I got the talk right at the beginning as I rejected treatment of any sort. It was interesting for me to listen to the details of the coming up end, if I didn't have any attempt of treatment. I was feeling half dead with my severe pneumia anyway. Docs ( 2 proffessors) in the room were amazed at my coolness about the whole deal & and making a swot analysis of my own health care decision, it would surely been an interesting documentary material. Well death is coming anyway, why suffer & cause my loved ones suffer along with me was my point & their arguments against mine were not convincing in anyway (my decision later on trying the treatment is based on a totally different reason), that I thought if they said I was dying soon, I probably wouldn't have believed that as well. I noticed right there & then that with their level of education and med experience, neither of the docs had an idea of the implications of the talk on the patient. I believe it's not something they can gain with education or normal practice, but only through being a relative of a dying patient. Hugs. Ebru

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2014 01:54AM stagefree wrote: Sham, Cancer treatment is very harsh on the body, both rads & chemo and AIs..Â  Yes yes and yes.. Ä°t is very normal.. Most chemos have various SEs like nausia, heartburn, fatigue, headaches & other body parts aches..Â  It is not only the meds causing pain in various parts of the body, but also the c-buggers trying to make new homes for themselves..Â  Most MOs are focussed on nausia meds for SEs, but in fact we all should be using ulcer meds as regular pill consumers.. Please check that with your med team, as some of these interact with some tx forms.. Should be prescribed accordingly..Â  Your mom is on anxiety meds already, I hope.. She needs that for peace of mind & in some cases ( mine at least) help the body relax despite the huge war going on in it..Â  Hope she feels relief soon.. Do ask for help from the med team for proper SE management. Sometimes when you don't speak, they may assume things are OK.Â  All of this aside, this is stage 4 cancer.. Sadly she might ( though I sincerely hope doesn't) experience discomfort of any sort imaginable despite the support of all meds available. So, please calm her ( and yourself) when such may ( though hope not) happens..Â  Hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2013 01:12PM stagefree wrote: OK first congrats on the shrinking tumors. As long as they are kept under control, we are cool about it, right? It is a good day to enjoy that part of the news. I remember reading some posts that kept on mentioning chemos not working one after another, which was so depressing. Taxol is good. Working for you. AND second time round.So we are happy about that. You have good many options still in your pocket, which you will need further ahead.Â  A couple of months ago, while I was on Taxotere & thinking what's next.. already had the Red Devil, Now the T Truck.. my DH reminded me these were helping me out to hunt down the cancer buggers. That I shouldn't feel like they were the enemies themselves. Feeling some of the worst SE's at that moment, I was like "oh yeah what do you know?" but thinking about it furher since then, I have somehow bought the idea and now feel calmer, if not friendlier towards the thought of chemo again.Â  I think your MO sounds too straightforward, not emphasizing with you. You, we, everyone knows these facts, we need to be told the details GENTLER, and one by one.. That's how I feel about it. Since we cannot turn back the clock for you to have the conversation again, why not focusing on the next one and asking some details on how to keep better QOL on treatment.Â  I am sure you are familiar with some of the chemos SE's, not all pull your hair out. Some are in fact gentler for many sisters than the AI's..which when first reading it, I was fascinated about btw.. Maybe being a part of the treatment plan according to such details we help you out. When I was first told to be put on Zoladex, I asked if there was a gentler alternative, so now I am on Lupron. Silly but I am not afraid of dying itself, but a shot in the bellyÂ . Never been NED so far, so I cannot comment on that, but I believe in managable QOL. Maybe MO could offer some stuff to lessen the SE's you are currently having. Already having Tamoxifen out of the list in just 4 months & praying Femara sticks around with me longer than that, I know the day will will come when I am left only a number of chemos to continue treatment. Daily QOL dear, please don't think too far ahead.Â  Hair is a great issue, for all of us. Wish the price of our treatment wasn't that high. Personally I prefer losing hair to having nausia like harsh SE. Cancer is cancer. Cancer sucks. Not having hair is for me mostly what everyone else around me should deal with. But the harsh nausia etc is totally what I am dealing on my own. But that's me...I am not the once attractive gal I was, with my skin mets, shrunk & brownish left boob, so DH is already fine with my baldness alreadyÂ . Well even if he is not, he has stuck with me for some more time anyway.. I hope! love & hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2013 07:42PM stagefree wrote: I won't repeat what the other gorgeous sisters already said, but want to share my experience the other day at the aquapark we went as family the first time since dx, and my first time in bathng suit, a proffesional basic arena one, with no support / bra inside. I chose this one cos it's covering more on the front so my skin mets don't show. I have a small boob, the other one's shrunk flat with chemo somehow... Never considered recon from day one, that's me. Learned later I couldn't have anyway. Dh is fine with the remaining one, so far., he said once he was in love with me, not my boobs, which would get uglier with age anyway.. of course there is some imbalance of my looks with the bathing suit on, so right before climbing for the highest slide with ds, I tucked my dh's poolcap as a fake boob before getting out of the pool. Not that I cared, I had nowhere else to put the cap. The slide was fun. Right after we were getting out of the pool, I realised my fake boob was right on my stomach in the bathing suit hahaha ðŸ˜³ðŸ˜³. Well I pushed it up and walked out of the pool as if it was the most normal thing in the world. Btw sun is totally banned for Xeloda users, who cares, just 2 days with ds who was sooo happy with mommy in the water again with him after 2 years. Worth the price. After a while dh asked for his cap back before getting in the pool... Well I grabbed it out of my bathing suit and handed it over... I had great time. I don't wear bras anymore. Choose appropriate clothing, trust me there are some cool stuff even for us.. But of course that's me. I know many feel recon is crucial to feel better about their bodies & I strongly respect them. But for me, already radiotherapy ruined skin offering nothing but what I am left with, I adopted the Italian / French approach.. Attract attention to my best parts.. I laughed my brains out when announced the most beautiful woman on 20th year highschool reunion, little did they know.. Focusing at my Pink hair & professional "porcelain makeup" hiding the severe facial rashes of my Xeloda, they didn't realise the weight I put on, my saggy legs as I can no longer excersice I hid under the long skirt!!! It sucks, no it sucks big time most of the time, even though I try to make fun of it most of the time. Know what, I cry very hard at times too. But then feel better at other times that I am still alive & not alone in this crappy new life. Thankful for each day I still get to spend time with my dh & ds. Will be glad to help you grab some great clothing rather than buying bras! Anytime dear.. And there are sewable breast covers shaped as bras you know, much more convenient. I don't even sew them, just tuck them in if I ever need too. Well my private secrets have all been releaved at last ðŸ˜. For you and anyone else interested... Hugs & much love, Ebru

Interestingly he switched the hours I took them instead of increasing the doses and I am much better right now. Especially for Xanax one of my physh meds, the daily dosage should be divided to two, for it acts only 8 hours- was my miracle. Hope you feel better soon.Â  Ebru

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2013 02:11PM stagefree wrote: Most is already said on steroids. What I can add on is: * Important to drink lots of plain water (not any fluid) on the day before, the day of and at least 4-5 days after your infusion to help flush the excess steroids & anything else your body doesnt need. * Taxanes are tough to handle, I was on Taxotere last year for 8 cycles, get what you say. I was put on Xanax & Lexapro by docs, but it was only after I visited a psychiatrist to have the dosage / using instructions revised properly it worked for me to sleep, indeed. My painkiller Tramadol also helped relax even if not sleep.Â  * Need oxygen & more oxygen.. the chemicals work on your whole system so your body needs to breathe more. Wearing light clothing and frequent walks (though not far, you can't make it I agree) helps too. * Red stuff, cherries, berries whatever to keep your blood levels up, so that you don't get more effected by the SEs.. maybe haven't already seen my famous watermelon white peel recipe!? I am serious. It has more than the red part offers for us. So eat it up sis.Â  hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 01:48PM stagefree wrote: Wandering spirit hi! You described more or less my dx with mets. Ä° had HOdgkin's lymphoma as primary cancer at 15. Now 39, almost 2 years after dx, already. You can see my treatment in my signature..Â  Took a while to absorb the reality with a 9 year old son but now living the new normal. Though ER +, hormonals failed me at first, tms skyroketed to almist 3000 at some point.. Now Xeloda has taken things under control..Â  One day at a time is the formula.. No pushing yourself too far.Â  Pleural effusion, as your mo said, is not the biggest issue.. Walking, deep breathing exercises, working with an incentive spirometer helps lots!Â  And tx also help resolve fluid of course.Â  Don't count the years.. enjoy the momentsÂ  :) Hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2014 11:06PM - edited Jan 8, 2014 11:12PM by stagefree Chris, Cry it away sis.. As looong as you need. Mom's best advice to me as she had a brief ride on this effing roller coaster herself..Â  People without experience can't and won't get you, so the more talk the worse it feels, sadly.Â  Extra bucks to a psychiatrist ( not psychologist) is worth it.. Hope you are on your mood meds EVERYDAY, not occasionally, cos they don't work properly otherwise.. A good psychiatrist will adjust your best dosage of them daily, if not already done so. And you can gossip about and curse at anything & anyone while with the psy, they have great responses for specific circumstances, trust me!!! Xanax needs to be taken 12 hours apart as it's effect lasts max 8 hours..the real effect keeps working for just a couple of hours.. So divide your daily dosage in two, if not already know that. My psy said not even some his colleagues know that..Â  Ä° was quite devastated to find out AÄ°s worked just a couple of months ( who am Ä° kidding?? Never worked, TMs skyrocketed each month!). Ä° had read on the boards for some AÄ°s are more tolerable, for others chemo is, at least some of them.. Ä° was so focussed on being happy to have my hair back on AÄ°s that Ä° had overseen my horrible SEs on them..Xeloda shocked me in a good way on my second date with him... Well .. WHAT DOES NOT KÄ°LL YOU WÄ°LL MAKE YOU STRONGER has been the exact case with it.. He liked me more finding out the heart attack (literally) he caused of his awesomeness (a chemo in pill form with no hair loss!) didn't back me down. So Our affair is still on, for now..Â  We are arming up to support you in your next adventure with chemo, yeah! We know our ways to deal with their SEs, each one of them! Never forget you are NOT (at least virtually) alone in this.Â  Cherish your family as they are, not them with the c-buggers.. Let your med team and BCO sisters help you with the rest ðŸ’ª. Hugs & love Ebru Edit: Ä° made sure my fave quote was not skipped in this long post, today's gift Â for you !!Â

Much scientific evidence shows operating on metastatic areas only help the cancerous cell travel faster on the lymphetic highway throughout your body, so cÄ±nsidering your past operations, the Med team most probably think it's best to treat well and look after your body, help it keep all energy for the fight, rather than recovering from yet another operation .. One thing to keep in mind is that it wouldn't hurt to try it, anyway right? :) I suggest you soak everything, including fruit, in apple vinegar for a while after washing & then rinse..just to be on the safe side..and apple vinegar boosts the immune system :)Â  Some veggies, like tomatoes, are more effective when a bit cooked, just a reminder… My Cancer dietician warned me against to much juicing of raw veggies & fruit for overconsumptioun of fiber. Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 12:43PM stagefree wrote: Caryn, I'll try to find it & share :) Musiclover,Â pomegranates are being processed by the liver (as does many cancer drugs), I was told by the Cancer Dietician, new studies suggest better beware than regret.. so she cut it off my diet.. And I was juicing it like day & night till then :)) Drugs especially like Xeloda have very complex formulas, not even supplements like Ritalin allowed with them.. I wasn't on AIs when I got that diet.. but it's a straightforward one, applicable in most cases I trust.. Still alive, I am :) Oh and it IS quite an expensive dietician btw, so sharing makes me feel better, cost is justified now ;) hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: Dear all, Been quiet I know.. But felt you all by my side throughout.. Turns out summer, sund and hot weather are not favorable in my condition.. TMs still on the rise a bit.. Well it's autumn already, so hope Xeloda will make peace with the surrounding contitions and kick back in. Since hormonals did not like me before, I want to stick with hair protecting chemo as long as possible .. Dh hates short hair & Ds is still too young to grasp things as they are.. Of course, already started viewing new hair trends in case I ll go for wigs again ;) Great that Xeloda (which gave me my first heart attack right at the start) is my great friend now that I am constantly on heart pills for the past 3 years.. Strongly suggest newbies to read my past threads on its SEs and nutrition advices :)) Well, today I said bye to Tramadol 100 mg, which had been my sole pain killer right from the start. I insisted on not moving on to stronger weapons immediately and confess have endured a 'bit of' pain especially during this past summer.. Keeping activities on low level, etc .. So feel confident my new handsome pain management doc has joined my team at the right time. Today :) we discussed matters in detail and he prescribed a codain based coctail :))) for regular use and another strong weapon for breakthrough pains.. Feel happy.. Feel relaxed.. Finally the pain is under control. I am confident I made the decision to move on to new meds right on time. No more driving. Dh already took away my car, knowing my fast driving instincts o well .. But am still allowed to go to grocery store etc when I must.. Driving has always been my hobby loved my cars and probably that's why I resisted so long not to use much meds till now.. Susan & Sue who have been in Istanbul know that :) the city is much enjoyable with a car.. Well that's the end of another chapter now :) Still on Xanax & Lexapro for mood and anxiety control.. The yummy doc said we'll stick with those for noww.. Gals, please consult with a psychiatrist for mood meds and pain doc for pain control.. MOs can only know as much on those c- buggers .. My cardiologist is still in control of my heart and pulminologist ( also an immunology specialist) closely watching mu PE and the rest.. The headmaster of the team is of course DH, dealing with his crazy wife still. I am so blessed to have him by my side. He is writing a book on history, hope I get to see it published.. DS finally got the notion mommy is really sick.. A great success of the family I believe.. Not to have him worry for mommy for this long! Now he is 10, just started middle school.. Just another accomplishment to have witnessed that as well.. Guess I'll need 24/7 house assistance from now on, so will be hiring a full time maid soon. Not my fave to have a stranger living in the house, but my bone mets disagree with that :)) Life's been good.. Met so many gals during this journey and based on my experiences, what I suggest most is PLEASE IGNORE ANY SORT OF NEGATIVITY in your life.. Especially during the past few months, I was so surprised to experience such horrific pain right after I got sad, angry, overwhelmed .., you name it.. Interesting but true.. Very true. Not easy to deal with everything so possitively I KNOW, yet communicating this with you loved ones DOES help. This has been the greatest discovery of tje past few months living in pain hell.. Btw I am still around, my post may sound a bit like wrapping things up.. NOPE! I want to meet the newbies, that's why I keep on writing.. Hopefully will post more often .. I know you all miss my photos and all.. Elections are coming up in Turkiye.. Fingers crossed we'll finally get rid of this tall mustache! Codaine is good ;) well life's rewarding me being a good girl all my life.. Now I am a junkie! Haha ;))) Hugs, kisses & love Ebru Dx 4/9/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 1, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 4/11/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/24/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/8/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole), Zoladex (goserelin) Chemotherapy 6/8/2016 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 08:04AM stagefree wrote: Dear Musiclover, I had posted some details on my diet after consulting with a MBC Dietician.. Which worked through tough times.. I had felt I was doing my best to support my system then..Â  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/79... Once the shock of dx is through, that took about a full year for me, I was back on my feet leading the new normal life, with regular psychiatrist appointments ( for fine tuning & mood meds prescriptions).. Now I only visit him occasionally.. But still on mood meds 24/7.. Asked MO if I could quit them a couple of months ago, feeling quite OK, got the answer "no, cos they're the reason you feel Ok!" ;)) There was a great comic in fb about a month ago.. Two cavemen chatting, trying to keep warm sitting by the fire they just lit.. One said to the other "well we are doing everything right.. Get plenty of sleep, eat organic stuff, have no stress, regularly exercise & live in unpoluted environment..yet none of us live past 30!"Â  Please don't judge your past life, things happen.. We keep walking .. As the Johnnie Walker ad says :)) Hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2015 10:27PM stagefree wrote: Dear all, Brain MRI turned out clean! :))))))))) MO is relieved as we made sure another Neurologist Oncologist, and two seperate radiologists examined the results. Well, I can manage moving & all on my own again, another great news! Maybe this was sort of an attack, as you mentioned. This is the bright side of the coin. On the other side, we haven't found out what causes this, yet. But so relieved I can now be with my son again. I love you all so much, you know your support helps me pull myself together and move on. We all have so much crap going on. But then, life is going on, STILL :)))) It means soooo much to have you all by my side, while you keep dealing with your own delicate issues.. I'll check out nerve pain relief meds, as I have been using Contramal during all this, but it didn't really relieve much. One can be amazed how much pain she can endure.. Well, what I have been going through was definitely worse than giving birth. And yes, I should be my own advocate on pain Management. Meanwhile, hot water bags help a bit. Interestingly, numbness of my chin got a bit better during the last few days of my off week from Xeloda. And we were focussed on Zometa all this time. More tests are waiting, including a possible spinal fluid check. But we don't rush for now as there is little time of school break left for my son and he missed me so much. So happy I am not back here with horror stories, yet : D Hugs & love to all Ebru :)

Posts.Title: So I am riding the ANXIETY Bus right now... Fitztwins

Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: Dear all, Been quiet I know.. But felt you all by my side throughout.. Turns out summer, sund and hot weather are not favorable in my condition.. TMs still on the rise a bit.. Well it's autumn already, so hope Xeloda will make peace with the surrounding contitions and kick back in. Since hormonals did not like me before, I want to stick with hair protecting chemo as long as possible .. Dh hates short hair & Ds is still too young to grasp things as they are.. Of course, already started viewing new hair trends in case I ll go for wigs again ;) Great that Xeloda (which gave me my first heart attack right at the start) is my great friend now that I am constantly on heart pills for the past 3 years.. Strongly suggest newbies to read my past threads on its SEs and nutrition advices :)) Well, today I said bye to Tramadol 100 mg, which had been my sole pain killer right from the start. I insisted on not moving on to stronger weapons immediately and confess have endured a 'bit of' pain especially during this past summer.. Keeping activities on low level, etc .. So feel confident my new handsome pain management doc has joined my team at the right time. Today :) we discussed matters in detail and he prescribed a codain based coctail :))) for regular use and another strong weapon for breakthrough pains.. Feel happy.. Feel relaxed.. Finally the pain is under control. I am confident I made the decision to move on to new meds right on time. No more driving. Dh already took away my car, knowing my fast driving instincts o well .. But am still allowed to go to grocery store etc when I must.. Driving has always been my hobby loved my cars and probably that's why I resisted so long not to use much meds till now.. Susan & Sue who have been in Istanbul know that :) the city is much enjoyable with a car.. Well that's the end of another chapter now :) Still on Xanax & Lexapro for mood and anxiety control.. The yummy doc said we'll stick with those for noww.. Gals, please consult with a psychiatrist for mood meds and pain doc for pain control.. MOs can only know as much on those c- buggers .. My cardiologist is still in control of my heart and pulminologist ( also an immunology specialist) closely watching mu PE and the rest.. The headmaster of the team is of course DH, dealing with his crazy wife still. I am so blessed to have him by my side. He is writing a book on history, hope I get to see it published.. DS finally got the notion mommy is really sick.. A great success of the family I believe.. Not to have him worry for mommy for this long! Now he is 10, just started middle school.. Just another accomplishment to have witnessed that as well.. Guess I'll need 24/7 house assistance from now on, so will be hiring a full time maid soon. Not my fave to have a stranger living in the house, but my bone mets disagree with that :)) Life's been good.. Met so many gals during this journey and based on my experiences, what I suggest most is PLEASE IGNORE ANY SORT OF NEGATIVITY in your life.. Especially during the past few months, I was so surprised to experience such horrific pain right after I got sad, angry, overwhelmed .., you name it.. Interesting but true.. Very true. Not easy to deal with everything so possitively I KNOW, yet communicating this with you loved ones DOES help. This has been the greatest discovery of tje past few months living in pain hell.. Btw I am still around, my post may sound a bit like wrapping things up.. NOPE! I want to meet the newbies, that's why I keep on writing.. Hopefully will post more often .. I know you all miss my photos and all.. Elections are coming up in Turkiye.. Fingers crossed we'll finally get rid of this tall mustache! Codaine is good ;) well life's rewarding me being a good girl all my life.. Now I am a junkie! Haha ;))) Hugs, kisses & love Ebru Dx 4/9/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 1, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 4/11/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/24/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/8/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole), Zoladex (goserelin) Chemotherapy 6/8/2016 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2012 09:29AM stagefree wrote: I second what everyone else said so far. Life IS short, shouldn't stress over anything too much. I am also on a healthy diet, but aiming to occasionally enjoy some of the "no no"s myself as soon as my TM's are lowered to an acceptable level. Eating a cookie or two making you feel happy vs guilty afterwards, is the thing to watch out for. How you feel is more important than what you do. If going to enjoy it, go for it ;) My cousin replaced sugar with honey for my son's (allergic to all unhealthy happy food) cookies, which he loves so much BTW. Just an idea. For exercise, MO advised swimming (when chemo over) for my extensive bone mets, now that summer is over! Now will look for a clean pool.. I am currently just walking. All harsh movements are forbidden in my case, so I suggest you check with onc what is best for your specific case. I take a calcium, magnesium, zinc& vit d3 supplement everyday, subscribed by onc. Having said all this, I admit I am in a similar place as you are right now BTW. Hope we all feel better soon. It can't rain forever, as a sister put in her signature- I want to ( need to) believe this for us all. Love & hugs, Ebru

Been on Tax & X (which I had to quit after hospitalisation due to severe heart condition on the 3rd day). Upon dx, I was given 2-3 years. Posts.Title: Expected Life SPAMgirl jocanuck1951

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2012 10:00PM stagefree wrote: ktcloud, it is interesting, they gave you such a short-term expiration date, BOO to them! Lung, Liver & Brain mets are considered more dangerous, as far as I have learned. I was dx'd Hodgkin's Lenfoma when 16, 20 years back, the chemo just sucked in every possible way, and I also had a taste of the nasty radiotherapy given as such high doses back in the day! Of course I made an oath never to accept any therapy ever again if faced with a similar dx later in my life.Â  BAM, past April I was dx'd with mets to nodes, almost every bone I had, pleura & skin (for now). I immediately rejected therapy at first, sticking firmly with my oath. I felt betrayed, why now? They once told me past 10 years (not 5, right) I would be cancer-free. And it was 20 years!Â  My oncs spent a lot of time reassuring me chemo is nothing like what I once had, not because of the drugs themselves, but the drug industry has progressed so much dealing with the side effects. Yes, tried & true. Now on Taxoterrible, the cycles pass as a breeze, condisering past experience. I have been informed radiotherapy too is not once it was, although I have no chance receiving any more of it. Â  So much already said, I am glad to have accepted therapy. I wake up each morning and see my loving-hubby right next to me, and my 7-year-old son jumping in our bed with yet another lego truck he has built! It is surely worth it for me. And the stats ... well the h... with them. They have already been proven wrong. Why not again, for the opposite this time.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2017 10:00AM stagefree wrote: Hi Talpha, As much as this is a personal decision, work at the end of the day is for money. Health is more important. If you are willing to give up some luxury, why not? Some do have to work.. and they don't even have the luxury to ask this question even. Your body is at war and need all focus and energy possibly can devote to that.. well that's something money can't buy. On the other hand, some sisters say working distract them and they feel normal- ok.. for me, I have accepted my reality, closed down my business right after dx and live each sec enjoying and ignoring all possible stress.. also have kicked out toxic people out of my life.. my cancerland environment is still managable this way. I have new hobbies, new friends.. consider it maybe? As for panic attack, it's most normal. Each one of us need a psychiatrist, which I have one, and use regular mood & anxiety pills. I even have them adjusted to each new therapy.. I have an oncology psychiatrist, oncology dietician, pulmonologist, cardiologist and pain doc on my team of docs. You can't expect your MO&RO to deal with all . It took 5 years experience to have come to this point. Glad to be sharing with you. Hope you find your ideal pace in this new normal soon Hug.

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2016 03:20AM stagefree wrote: hi, I've been on Zometa for almost 5 years. I can say I look forward to the next cycle the last few days waiting for it, I feel my bones need it. SEs are the last thing to consider for us, cos all treatment have a variety of SEs anyway.. And long term SEs? I hope I live that long to see them! :)) I tried off treatment for a while but qol dissappered immediately. At this stage, treatment is to provide qol over anything else.. If you consume Zyrtec the day before, during the day & the day after, the SEs are minimal. Also, drinking gallons of water. And DO ask for a longer infusion time. Normally they prefer 15 minute infusion.. Ask for 45 min ( for Zometa) and see it's sooo much more tolerable. Zometa has been in the market much longer than Xgeva.. Onj is a risk with both meds.. So is death ;)) Mood is the best meds. And trusting your team of docs. MBC is yucky.. Hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2014 10:55PM stagefree wrote: Tina, First thing first: If not on regular mood meds, please do start using them after consulting a pyschiatrist asap.Â  I have a 9,5 year old so get how you feel about hair, which is really the least of our problems but not for them. They feel "things" about what they see.. We of course do not share each and every SE of treatment, our experiences with our visits to the "dark places" with them mostly, including DHs, trying to protect them from feeling sad. Which, I think is the hardest JOB.. For me at least..Â  I am blessed with the luxury to send DS for stay overs to grammys as we live in the same city ( even arranged his school bus accordingly for such urgent times) so that he is away when I need to flush my dark thoughts mostly alone..Â  DH tries to help , wants to share, but after almost 3 years of experience I know it only adds more burden on him and does not make me feel any better. Â  My first visit to the psychiatrist was to have the mood meds prescribed, wasn't expecting anything more. Turned out speaking a bit worked wonders. I had a couple more visits just to chat after that.Â  You girls are lucky, wigs in the US are ROCK! I don't know if it's already too late, but I once met a lady in infusion room who cut her hair before treatment & had her wig made with it. Wished I met her before shaving off my waist length natural blonde hair before first Tx... Maybe the idea helps any one of you ladies. Anyway my solution to hair loss was going wig shopping with Ds and had him choose various ones with me. He felt empowered against the embarressment choosing which to wear when, for me :)Â  Trust me, as long as you are alive and you can hug them & they can have that mommy smell ( how bad you think you smell with the chemo smell that doesn't ever wash off !!!), everything's fine. I greet Ds each day he arrives from school and take my afternoon nap - not before as I fear I might not hear the doorbell ( and don't as I sleep too deeply) - when he prepares his own snack, does his homework & play until Dh arrives and calls in / heats up dinner from the fridge before gently waking me up. He is grateful I am with them still, each new day. The house work is nothing compares to that for him, I know by heart.Â  I sometimes shop for new clothes and sering me dress up makes both of them so very happy, as I am mostly in my sweats when at home. I decided to do this more than occasionally when Ds arrived one day from school and asked "what's the occasion, you are dressed up?" When all I had on was my jeans and a tshirt!!!Â  Easier said than done we all KNOW, but I will say it anywayÂ  One day at a time! Just cherish each new morning you still can wake upto being with them and ask for all meds available from your med team ( as they might assume you are fine when you don't) for your QOL during this time.Â  Love & hugs Ebru

Please consider taking meds for anxiety & depression. They are a normal part of your therapy. I was surprised when my MO first suggested them, but found out it HELPS a great deal. You need to sleep. Sleep will help your therapy.Â  I cannot say having children is meant for everyone. So it won't help regretting your past decision. You could have had a child & be worrying about his/her feelings of your current situation right now. So it's better not to dig that deep & jump to conclusions. Now it is time to focus on yourself, take care of yourself, to do whatever that makes you happy & cherish each moment you still have with your loved ones. You just took a breath & then let it out, right? It's gone forever. You might or might not have the chance to take another one tomorrow, so can't really plan things that far. But taking the next breath right now, you know you still live with it. Focus on that one. Soon that will be gone too, so better not have more regrets than you already have. Â  Â  warm hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2013 09:30PM stagefree wrote: I second Caryn. Stage IV means treatment for life. Even for the lucky ones who can be on hormonal therapy or the ones using chemo in pill form for some time, we all have to be poked at least once every month- 3 months for blood work, scans, therapies. Considering the good number of ladies with recurrences who only can at best ( if not had double mastectomy before) use one arm for all this..And the truth is we all get to taste the variety number of IV chemos someday, if not today. I had followed Lynn's thread which has great info, so please check that out if not already. I've seen / heard people have their ports inserted to various parts of their bodies. One day in the infusion room, the lady sitting next to me zipped down her pants to open her abdomen waiting for the nurse. What was she doing???!! I was an infusion room virgin until then, to admit. 20 years back, I had my first set of treatment in a private room using my arm veins. Well the nurse came and gently accessed her port on the right side of her abdomen, I guess close to her liver. Well that was cool. Â Maybe not in the infusion room, but I decided that was better than a port in my chest, if possible. I also liked Ann's (Coolbreeze) idea to have inserted in her arm.Â BTW I still haven't mine inserted yet. My primary onc is taking her time, I guess, to work out on all possible treatment in pill form before suggesting the port (that's how they prefer in my country). As far as I know there are almost no early stagers with ports here, so it was interesting for me to find out on BCO that early stagers in the US especially do have ports inserted even for 6 cycles of chemo treatment, then have it out.. I can use one arm for everything & it is already tired before my first cancerversary. I would have had my petite power port inserted already if I was in the US, trusting majority of the positive views of ladies with ports on BCO. Hope you decide for the best... Â  Ebru

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2014 09:05PM stagefree wrote: Dear Raro, We already know it's one day at a time, right? Well, I added to that, one activity per day.. maybe many other sisters have already done so. Figured the more plans I had and not accomplished, the worse I felt. Now I do feel better. Just started my morning walking this week, hope to keep on with it. Well I am quite active on twitter, Facebook & apps on iPad. NO TV. I hate it. Feel dumbing me. But rent movies on iTunes is fine. :) If not feeling like going to the movies. Not really a reading as much, can't concentrate much on long scripts.. Music is my life.. Keeps my spirits up. Interestingly, I am very happy to my BCO sisters & family for support. But prefer spending more time with people not knowing my situation lately. Guess life somehow goes on hopefully for more time, with the QOL manageable for me. So, why not talk something else?? Somedays I even feel as if I am not sick, of course after popping my narcotics killing the bone pain ;) I am not in need to have many people around me, can self entertain.. hope you do find what you want to do soon. Purpose is to stay alive in a better mood sis. My favourite philosopher summed it long ago with his autobiography title "Killing Time". Not just us, everybody else does that. Difference is we are aware of our mortality each second, whereas others think they are immortal…. Well, that's what I think & believe. So try to let go of my pre-cancer dreams & plans and live each day as it comes along.. huge hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: "Ever wondered why all newborns cry? " asked my lifecoach the other day. I quickly replied him with my limited scientific background, to gasp for breath, to inflate his lungs, etc. He smiled and said "because he is scared, born to somewhere he never was before". And added that the fetus happily lived in his mother for 9 months, where it was warm & comfy and he was fed. That, it is the shock and fear of loosing all that makes the babies cry. Only after placed on his mother's breast to smell his comforting mom, he is persuaded he is still with her and it will be fine. He concluded all babies relax and sleep well after the first breastfeed. Having had this experience with my son, I loved this explanation, helped me accept my fears of dying and occasional crying are normal. I am soon (well according to the stats at least) going to die / born to somewhere I never was before. Hope it is the heaven described in my childhood :) It is OK to cry a little until I get used to my new home-to-be. Posts.Title: My Cancer Diet stagefree ShetlandPony

Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: I am posting as JCB51's request on some detail on my diet.Â  We have had cancer in the family for so long, it has been a sad, yet teaching experience over the years. My iron levels & everything else have always been low, seeing everything spinning occasionally even before dx, so you can imagine the levels of my first couple of months of chemo-induced anemia. Oncs in my country push for nutrition as a crucial part of the treatment, rather than supplements. I have had a strong diet from the start, first visiting a dietician focused on cancer patients to sort out a plan: First the no no's: grapefruit, pomegranate, green tea, anything fried, coke & similar, take away & packaged food of any kind, coffee, salt, sugar, anything with white flour, rice, alcohol, smoking, chocolate meat OK'ed: lamb, sea fish & turkey only. no beef, interestingly. I avoid consuming milk (Onc said may interfere with chemo), replaced it with yoghurt oil: only virgin olive oil Â  6 meals a day (at least) in moderate portions (not to upset my pleural effusions) 09:00: dried fruit tea, 2 egg whites, 1 egg yolk boiled / omlette, cheese with no salt, whole wheat flour bread, some walnuts 11:30: fruit salad, some almondsÂ  13:00: meatballs/steak of lamb or turkey, salad with all colors, steamed veggies/ veggie soup, bulghur / whole wheat flour pasta 16:00: some plain homemade yoghurt (I add a teaspoon of nigella seeds not interfers with chemo, checked with onc), some nutsÂ  19:00:Â meatballs/steak of lamb or turkey, salad with all colors, steamed veggies/ veggie soup, bulghur /Â whole wheat flour pasta 21:30: 2 fruit, some yoghurt It's boring, I know, but it works for me. I have a bite of chololate when I really crave for it, but stick to the diet mostly. Â Â  Jan (JCB51), no wonder you are craving for watermelon, the white part just beneath the peel that we normally throw away is in fact what is suggested for cancer patients. Eating / juicing that both really has helped in our blood levels.Â  During summer I juiced & ate cherries, cornellian cherries, blackberries, black mulberries, strawberries, damsons, grapes, peaches, nectarines, fresh pineapples (the center part especially) in HUGE amounts among everything else, mom kept showing up with a huge glass of something red at least once a day. Consuming all fruit & veggies with peel as much as possible, after washing in apple vinegar & rinsing twice, a boiled beetroot per day, pimentos, carrots, an artichoke per day (when available), celery roots, broccoli & of course lots of tomatoes. Needless to say all is organic. Also have dried fruits occasionally. Â  And finally grains, beans, chick peas, lentils, cooked with veggies / bulghur, or alone. I drink 2 lt of 8.22 PH water. My TM's were really high close to 1000 at the start, so I have been strict with the diet so far. Planning to avoid some restrictions as TM's get lower. Interestingly I got used to consuming healthy stuff. Always pushed myself to eat no matter how yucky everything tasted after chemo, considered eating as part of my medicine. After the third chemo it got easier. People in the waiting room with stage 0-1 conversing desperately did get on my nerves after some point though, 2 full hours of waiting after all..Made sure with the secreatry I'll have more privacy next time, should I wait that long. MO announced Navelbine first. She said it would be in pill form?!. OK this new info & maybe doable I thought, until she said the first dose had to be IV. Without a port & considering my already poor tried veins, I didn't jump very enthusiastically to that idea. Thank you all for your previous feedback btw. Knowledge IS power. She then said "wish you could do Xeloda". For the ones maybe who don't know my past experience with X, it gave me a good heart attack on just the 3rd day of the first cycle.. since which I am on heart meds. Small note, it was prescribed wrong back then, for me to take it with empty stomach .. that probably added to the outcome. But of course we never mentioned that to her (as she's already one of the top-notch Oncs in Turkiye), also considering like everyone else docs can make mistakes. DH & I both jumped to that idea, as we believe maybe it would be different this time. She was puzzled by our enthusiasm, which was a brief fun sec for the both of us. With her little knowledge of our real experience with X the first time round, she Â could have even thought us nuts to go back on a med that nearly killed me beforeÂ . Btw not yet quit Femara & Lupron. Will have my Lupron shot on Friday & keep taking Femara for the next 3 weeks. Gives me hope my brief adventure with AI's not yet over maybe. Though MO did admit she was hoping my journey on them would be much longer at this stage & was suprised it was way too short instead.Â  Anyway, I am a Xeloda girl right now. Will have a look on that one here in detail today. Feel much better for the moment, but it was a big bump for sure the other day. Now I am back up on my feet again! Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: I am posting as JCB51's request on some detail on my diet.Â  We have had cancer in the family for so long, it has been a sad, yet teaching experience over the years. My iron levels & everything else have always been low, seeing everything spinning occasionally even before dx, so you can imagine the levels of my first couple of months of chemo-induced anemia. Oncs in my country push for nutrition as a crucial part of the treatment, rather than supplements. I have had a strong diet from the start, first visiting a dietician focused on cancer patients to sort out a plan: First the no no's: grapefruit, pomegranate, green tea, anything fried, coke & similar, take away & packaged food of any kind, coffee, salt, sugar, anything with white flour, rice, alcohol, smoking, chocolate meat OK'ed: lamb, sea fish & turkey only. no beef, interestingly. I avoid consuming milk (Onc said may interfere with chemo), replaced it with yoghurt oil: only virgin olive oil Â  6 meals a day (at least) in moderate portions (not to upset my pleural effusions) 09:00: dried fruit tea, 2 egg whites, 1 egg yolk boiled / omlette, cheese with no salt, whole wheat flour bread, some walnuts 11:30: fruit salad, some almondsÂ  13:00: meatballs/steak of lamb or turkey, salad with all colors, steamed veggies/ veggie soup, bulghur / whole wheat flour pasta 16:00: some plain homemade yoghurt (I add a teaspoon of nigella seeds not interfers with chemo, checked with onc), some nutsÂ  19:00:Â meatballs/steak of lamb or turkey, salad with all colors, steamed veggies/ veggie soup, bulghur /Â whole wheat flour pasta 21:30: 2 fruit, some yoghurt It's boring, I know, but it works for me. I have a bite of chololate when I really crave for it, but stick to the diet mostly. Â Â  Jan (JCB51), no wonder you are craving for watermelon, the white part just beneath the peel that we normally throw away is in fact what is suggested for cancer patients. Eating / juicing that both really has helped in our blood levels.Â  During summer I juiced & ate cherries, cornellian cherries, blackberries, black mulberries, strawberries, damsons, grapes, peaches, nectarines, fresh pineapples (the center part especially) in HUGE amounts among everything else, mom kept showing up with a huge glass of something red at least once a day. Consuming all fruit & veggies with peel as much as possible, after washing in apple vinegar & rinsing twice, a boiled beetroot per day, pimentos, carrots, an artichoke per day (when available), celery roots, broccoli & of course lots of tomatoes. Needless to say all is organic. Also have dried fruits occasionally. Â  And finally grains, beans, chick peas, lentils, cooked with veggies / bulghur, or alone. I drink 2 lt of 8.22 PH water. My TM's were really high close to 1000 at the start, so I have been strict with the diet so far. Planning to avoid some restrictions as TM's get lower. Interestingly I got used to consuming healthy stuff. Always pushed myself to eat no matter how yucky everything tasted after chemo, considered eating as part of my medicine. After the third chemo it got easier. Â  EbruÂ  Dx 4/9/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 1, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 4/11/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/24/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/8/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole), Zoladex (goserelin) Chemotherapy 6/8/2016 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 19, 2017 06:38AM stagefree wrote: Anita, Been there, TMs almost 3000, Xeloda is a big gun. It kills c-buggers as it finds them, so the idea of a flare at the first couple of cycles seems normal. Your state of mind is important, so is your right approach to use the chemo. You should take daily doses exactly 12 hours apart. You shouldn't consume dairy protein, definitely no milk. You shouldn't consume grapefruit and pogmenarete. They all interact in the liver, where Xeloda's main site of work! You should have real protein, young meat , that is lamb, not cow. No deep sea fish allowed. No fries. No packaged food. Deep red, deep green fruit and veggies, prefferably fresh. Have afternoon nap, go to bed early and have shower twice a day. Water's healing power is immense. Cut carbohydrates as much as you can, they equal sugar you know. Drink water, prepare cinnamon and lemon flavored bottles. Don't read and believe anything .. I wasn't supposed to last a week at dx, it's been 5 full years! Not the sick, but the one that's time is due dies. Get stress out out of your life.. easy. I even kicked mom out of my daily life. No drama queen is allÄ±wed anymore around. It's my life. For liver eat tons of artichoke! We get poisoned in the kidneys with chemo & all.. have okra on your plate.. sometimes you cannot eat anything, nausia yep! Light youghurt with crackers help. Also can find roasted chickpeas at Turkish grocery stores to help with the stomach acid. I had HFS on the face dear, and dealt with it.. don't worry, you can manage it! X was good.. wish I could stay longer on it.. no dairy with x! Don't forget! Hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: Â  In a mother's womb were two babies. One asked the other: "Do you believe in life after delivery?" The other replies, "why, of course. There has to be something after delivery. Maybe we are here to prepare ourselves for what we will be later. "Nonsense," says the other. "There is no life after delivery. What would that life be?" "I don't know, but there will be more light than here. Maybe we will walk with our legs and eat from our mouths." The other says "This is absurd! Walking is impossible. And eat with our mouths? Ridiculous. The umbilical cord supplies nutrition. Life after delivery is to be excluded. The umbilical cord is too short." "I think there is something and maybe it's different than it is here." the other replies, "No one has ever come back from there. Delivery is the end of life, and in the after-delivery it is nothing but darkness and anxiety and it takes us nowhere." "Well, I don't know," says the other, "but certainly we will see mother and she will take care of us." "Mother??" You believe in mother? Where is she now? "She is all around us. It is in her that we live. Without her there would not be this world." "I don't see her, so it's only logical that she doesn't exist." To which the other replied, "sometimes when you're in silence you can hear her, you can perceive her." I believe there is a reality after delivery and we are here to prepare ourselves for that reality.... Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 04:05PM - edited Dec 16, 2012 04:06PM by stagefree Having just received the news that my CA 15-3 almost tripled in only 2 months & I am so eager (!) to hear what my MO's plans are for me tomorrow, I agree with Jen that cancer is no black /white. If that was the case, I am sure we would have had a complete cure out of it by now. There are lots of brilliant docs working to find the cure.Â  People have different approaches, for some it's misdiagnosis, others, miracles, some others God's will & the rest hear stories of a friend of a friend.. I have one story from my doc (and a first person info indeed) that I have already posted here as well, thinking it made me feel good, maybe it would make some of you feel good as well. I respect them all, the variety makes it worthwhile to spend hours on the boards. If I heard exactly how I felt / thought from each & every one of you, it wouln't make sense to visit here anyway. So I tend to pick & stick to every bit of positive input in each post. This helps me keep sane & feel supported & hugged with the virtual love of you all here.Â  Being a relatively newbie still here, I have come to realize that counting & hoping for years, months, days, hours, seconds is not the point, for me. As long as I have the QOL, living my life "normally" as much as possible, it IS OK. Be it a year or 10 really is not the point for me. Arguing in my head Â further of "if's" just is too tiresome and even more depressing. Having made peace with this thought, I stopped counting time, hoping for miracles.. BUT a cure definitely is welcome anytimeÂ ! Ebru EDIT: CA tripled to almost 1200!

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 10:12AM stagefree wrote: With respect to all previous posts, I believe it is tomato & tomato read differently. I believe we all have a full glass of water to start with. With our choices throughout our lives against the things we are faced with, some of us take a small sip every now and then, while others drink theirs all faster. In the end when the glass is empty, it is over for us. That's what I consider our small (but crucial) input to our personal destiny. I think I couldn't have any peace with what I am going through as fair, considering otherwise. That's our difference from plants & animals in the wild. I think only they live & die naturally in full sense. Thinking we drink coke (let aside alchohol), smoke (actively or passively), live in cities with severe pollution or in a small cabin in the forest, exercise or not, take a drug for each time we feel "sick" knowing even the most innocent could have serious side effects for the lucky few, we determine the speed of our end upto some point, even though even the ones doing all the right stuff could still be doomed with cancer or any other disease, which is their destiny in the purest sense. My mentor exampled this as people having to sleep more at nights take slower breaths, then ones stay awake later who breathe faster. But as the number of breaths they each have are pre-determined (and of course differs individually) making the choice to go to bed early or not even puts the responsibility of our lives on our personal selves. That's fascinating, for me at least. Makes me feel better than a death-sentenced prisoner waiting for his execution day to come.Â  Have I told you before I am a philosophical major? Thanks for bearing with me.... love & hugs, Ebru

Lost all hair on body ( except legs of course as I needed them most, ugh)!!!Â  Anyway, I read some research where Taxotere might cause permanent hair loss.. Well glad that's not the case for you.. My hair was thin and grew back very slowly too. Wearing mohawk style for almost 1,5 years, regularly shaving most of it really helped. Ooops secret revealed :) I AM a rock n roll girl so got the idea easily.. My dh & ds were very supportive. I still don't have the hair I once had but regular shaving, biotin shampoo (just twice a week, let it get oily, your scalp needs it) and eating rainbow colors surely helped a lot. I used no supplements.Â  Hope you feel more confident with your hair asap with quick improvement.Â  Almond oil is used generally here as a mask to hair for helping the scalp come to its senses for more hair growth.. Some women put it in their mascara tubes even to grow their eyelashes, so no harm.. Has been used for centuries.. Some insisted it really works on both hair and eyelashes.. Mom (bc survivor?!) once mentioned about mixture of vitamin e tube with pressed garlic mask on the head.. I said no thank you! She did it herself and has male lion hair now, though cannot be sure it was the garlic. Cos she did lots of things. Her pharmacy suggested the garlic formula!Â  I also figured my head needed to breathe so as soon as I had some hair, I put away all wigs, scarfs & hats.. Some people also insist standing under the rain is a great treat to hair.. Umbrella manufacturers probably hate this idea.Â  Good luck & hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 10:12PM stagefree wrote: Musiclover, Glad you fell better now. It is quite normal to have a breakdown with a sane mind.. so working on it to blur the facts stabbing your heart does work.. mood meds are for that as everyone else has suggested.. It takes a time to adjust to this phase of your life, no matter who you consult, which med you take, how much support you receive.. we all have been there. For some, it is a couple of months, others a couple of years and rest mmmm never… well all I can say about this is that I hope & pray you belong to the first group.Â  In my case, each visit to the oncology department brings both misery & relief.. you can guess the misery part.. I am relieved it's not my son but me dealing with this. Having had childhood cancer before and witnessed mom's hopeless sadness which she couldn't hide in her eyes, I can somehow guess how much harder it can be to live this bullshit (sorry for the language) with your child.Â  So when I come back home, I try to make the best of it, also already said by many.. Enjoy my time with DS, let all toxic people get out of my life as each sec is precious, not to be wasted for anyone who is not worth it.Â  Since I have already retired, I have all the time in the world to do whatever I want ( as much as I can afford it) when I am not sleeping. And sometimes doing nothing and enjoying the laziness makes me feel so good.Â  Hey, what's the worst thing that can happen to a MBC gal? Die? Well without it, we will die someday anyway, so it's really no big deal. The deal is to make the most of it, until that happens :) Easier said than done, but I feel blessed to have been informed beforehand I should make better use of the only life that I have, rather than work my brains out & worry about stupid things & people until I die. :) That's me of course. And I too have nervous breakdowns myself.. which is good, to let it out. We need that as well. After all, that's what tears are for ! I can sincerely say I was't any happier before MBC.. As one gets older, everything becomes a routine.. of course I would love to see my 9-year-old graduate, marry, have kids.. but seeing children who lose their parents early and still move on with their lives, is a relief.. They are much stronger than we think, I guess… Still I admit I do have fantasies of DS getting married at 13 so that I may see my DIL ha ha ha :)Â  As my favourite philosopher Feyerabend puts it, we are "Killing Time" here anyway.. I hope the next level where we go as angels ( I want purple wings btw) is cooler than here, cos we already got our share of misery.. I believe in the eternal equality of beings in the universe.. So don't really feel jealous why I am not one of those Victoria Secret models.. Or a nobel prize winner novelist.. :) I am sure our time will come.. just wait! and try to focus on the broader picture.. it cannot end like this.. Not logical scientifically, nor religiously (if one is a believer)..Â  I am chatty tonight..Â  hugs & love Ebru

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2013 10:06AM - edited Sep 25, 2013 10:15AM by stagefree They probably have already looked at it, still let me ask , what is your CRP level?? They looked at other stuff in my blood cancer-related, when I was hospitalised last year. A relative who is surgeon suggested this & it was soon figured I was severely infected. Have you consulted with your Phychiatrist on the dosages? Mine explained these meds, Xanax and alike in particular work in 8-hour intervals, so instead of dose increase he divided the daily dose previously prescribed by another doc into 2, to be taken in 12 hour intervals. Worked wonders. And tell me about the brain zaps & all. All were gone in a short while. My current psy rocks! Please everyone go to a psychiatrist for these meds, even some of them don't know how to prescribe the meds properly, mine confessed sadly.. Hope you feel better soon dear. Hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 10:15AM - edited Sep 11, 2012 10:27AM by stagefree Annie, I am sorry for what you are going through. You have enough crap to handle already and now this. I hope you decide for the best.. Your husband's acts being cheating or not aside, he clearly has an ADDICTION to porn and like any other addict, he probably has lived the past 16 years in denial. That's probably why he has not confessed earlier, but only did when he suspected he was caught. Just like anyone else with addiction to something, say like alcohol usually does. I remembered a Meg Ryan movie portreying an Addict (of alchoholism) & some famous guy I cannot recall now acting as her husband, when I read your post. I say all this, since you asked, but I am confident it really does not matter how long I just go on with facts of rationality..since people are not acting rational many times in their lives. Only you can decide for yourself, whether he is SINCERELY staying with you, or as a consequence of the 20-year-old obligation called marriage. Whether you have that special bond to keep you together until the rest of your life..ask your heart? Big hugs & love Ebru

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 11:43AM - edited Sep 6, 2012 11:45AM by stagefree Upon dx, all relatives rushed from all around Turkiye & abroad (no kidding, DH's uncle came all the way from the US) in our house for a last visit before I took off to heaven! Imagine my psychology then. Thank G*d, I am at a much better place now.Â  The beauty of being here is that we provide each other information, support, friendship, humour, whatever we all need..we have sad days, but then we have better ones following. My mentor said in one of my visits "just like the day following the night, summer following winter, we have good days and bad days. Living one day at a time is easier just like living the day and not worrying about the night to come. Enjoy the moments as much as you have them". We will think about what is waiting ahead when that day comes, THEN. It is not so easy doing that, but then we are all lucky to be here to share & support each other. I also say to myself when I feel really good (which, honestly speaking, is not very frequent these days), I do not "feel" cancer, and try not bothering myself with the battle going on in my body. Camillegal, how do you insert photos? Thanks.Â  EbruÂ

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2013 05:13AM stagefree wrote: One day... One week...one month.. Year maybe? I am ready for the talk any minute now. Currently on the chemo which nearly killed me and know what? Not only my TM's have been coming to their senses, but I notice my terrible chest skin mets have been healing. Sorry doc, but this is BCO's success so far. She almost put me on another chemo, where I objected and wanted to retry x,having read so much on it here. Now that I am on heart meds anyway, it's a calculated risk we are taking, saving that other chemo for later. Also know what? My onc wasn't hopeful when saw my situation at the start, now says I'm her best patient.. Docs try their best to help us in either way, based on med records we so depend on outselves fir more hope each second. But even those records don't mean anything after some point. Remember some sisters (bad name memory sorry) passing away all of a sudden when weren't doing that bad????? So for me, I listen to my body now and decide EACH day how to live in it the best that I can. Some days it says take things slow, other days it says don't get out of the bed, hold your pee some more.. But every now and then there are some wonderful days when I even forget I have MBC, rare but I still do. As much as I respect my med team, it is my body who will give me the talk that I will act upon, when the day comes... Hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 03:37AM stagefree wrote: Brenda you are right, there are times when I do wonder what if ... but then remember the story told by my mentor: A king was called to negotiate with the neighbor country's king someday. Having discussed the matter with his closest men, all objected that this was clearly a setup to murder him. He thought hard but went anyway. And murdered as his men rightfully guessed. They were angry, getting ready for a war.. The priest visited them to pray for their success. He heard one of the men saying how he wish the king listened to them & not go to be murdered. Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 10:59PM stagefree wrote: A simple answer is that we are terminal beings. some of us die from heart attacks, others in car accidents, the rest from many other things we all can think about. Think about a newborn dying just 10 minutes after put in her/his mother arms. Such is life, there are no definite answers, if so we most probably will not be receiving them until the day we are supposed to & are ready to do so.Â  My mentor occasionally jokes that there's only a limited space & sources on earth & we have to leave after sometime for the good of the new ones born each dayÂ . As much as I feel devasted at times struggling with the reality of my mortality, I still feel lucky to have understood how valuable each second we have in this journey called life. Just before dx, my main problems were work-related, were considering buying a new house, arguing with DH over the silliest things, etc. After dx, I found out I started enjoying life much more, feel happier each day I wake upto, not planning the chores & jumping out of bed to do them immediately. Instead I relax lazily for a while, wait for my son to jump in & play with him for a while. I'm not acting Pollyanna 24/7, but have already figured it's better trying to find tiny bits of things to feel better rather than let yourself caught up in the bad bad thoughts. hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: May 3, 2013 09:21PM - edited May 3, 2013 10:14PM by stagefree 1.What is your favorite song at the moment? http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7-0lV5qs1Q 2.You mention your brother often, what is so special about him? I have a brain damaged brother.. i am barely 15 months older than he is and we have always been very close.Â  (i am the only sibling he'll obey because i am older than he is.)Â  He was given a small house when my mom died and here is a pic of his mulch.Â  he politely asks the neighbors is he can rake their leaves in the fall and have them.Â  the yard is about - I'm not sure = about 35' by 20'.Â  He uses the mulch but also gives it to volunteer community gardens.. what a nut.Â  He won't even give me one bucket... "Mary - the mulch is for the poor! Â He is out working, rain or shine, every day.Â  He'll call occasionally and tell me his is coming out to help me with yard work.Â  I just adore him because he is sooo truly good.Â  he goes to Mass once or twice a day, works full time at the post office and does good works for people... paints their house for free.. things like that. Â Â  the tomato plants are on the right. I have also taught him many duets.. songs from musicals and kid songs.Â  here we are playing 'row, row, row your boat'.Â  you can see how happy I am.. he is such a wonderful trip.Â  My little sisters must have been teased about him.. They don't like him at all really.Â  He manage to graduate from college (my dad was a professor and that helped) but went to a very special special=ed school. I have him over for dinner once or twice a week..... if he is not too busy. 3. Can you tell us about one of your childhood memories: When I was a kid there was a nursing home 2 blocks up from our house run by nuns. Starting when I was 7, my mother sent me up every early afternoon in the summers and on Saturdays. (I would swim at 4 pm. with my dad and siblings.Â  She was very committed to the idea of service to one's fellow men.. When i was first 'hired' I thought I would be playing the piano for the residents. That never happened except for a few times. I helped them to the bathroom, fed them, read to them en masse, kept them warm with little blankets knitted by the altar society. I loved it and made many old friends. It was very very sad when they died. It took me a couple years to get used to the stream of death. I was always shocked when they would actually get sick and die. A few years later I started playing the organ at their funerals. Their sons and daughters loved that.... and I was astounded at the money. The funeral home took care of the 'arrangements'.. They still do. I still occasionally visit a funeral home in my neighborhood. I had a very good friend who went to live there at age 93. She said don't you dare come see me when I am dying. Well, I heard she was dying and quickly drove over to see her, but she has just died moments before. When her daughter came up to Kansas City to put her in the home she said "Quick - take whatever you want of my possessions so Judy won't get everything. I chose a huge aqua Fiestaware platter which I use all the time Â Judy was fine with that. 4. You mentioned playing the organ at funerals. Any specific memory you would like to share with us? Here in Kansas, a brother of a friend of mine, a fireman with a gambling and drinking problem, committed suicide in jail after being picked up for driving under the influence. One of my free lance jobs is playing the organ at funerals. He lived in on the northwestern side of the metro where the houses are pink, grey and crumbled, surrounded by wild dogs, and sometimes have Chief's logos painted full size on the side of the house that has NO windows. Tattoo parlors abut homemade churches of questionable denomination and the roads have no curbs or drainage conduits. William was a bagpiper. After the funeral, which was well attended by sturdy legged firemen whose pants were all too tight, who sported handlebar mustaches and shaved heads and probably had Harley-Davidson wannabees in their detached sheds, 25 firefighters gathered in the vestibule with 8 fully dressed bagpipers.Â  A fireman said "We will sound the final alarm for our brother William" They had brought at least 8 big brass bells (the kind that used to ring in firehouses to call the firefighters and dangle above the front of the trucks). The 8 bells started clanging in a reverberating church of stucco and tile, theÂ bagpipersÂ started playing, and the huge old church bell started peeling. For at least 3 minutes this unbelievably loud cacophony sounded. The congregation was clustered at the back of the church by the firemen and bagpipers. After about a minute of this wonderful noise, everyone broke into the most unfettered sobbing I have ever witnessed. Not a person was spared from the sobs of utter sorrow.Â  When the clamor died, one of the firefighters, I guess to lighten the mood, said "Dang it - Bill owed me ten bucks". The very elderly mother of William opened her purse and gave the firefighter a ten dollar bill which he stuck in his pocket to the dismay of all the other firefighters. Life is very short. 5. You have mentioned more than once your passion for playing & teaching music. Can you share some of your music with us? http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gsXQAhe8uYY http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qr_sl_UJdKE Â

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2013 10:19AM stagefree wrote: Judie, I spent last summer in harsh pain, I hug you, but gently! My pulmonologist warned me that I could have that after removal of the fluid in the pleura, since the lining is reshaping & the lungs are hopefully inflating back. She also admitted it could take a couple of months, which it did!!!! I hated taking deep breaths, hickups & yawning mostly. Don't even ask about coughing!. I felt my ribs "breaking" with each of those. I bended to hug my knees (I invented it) each time I had to any of those, to feel less pain. No pain meds helped, was already told that as well. If what you are experiencing is similar to my experience, it's MORE than "just" bone pain. This is severe bone mets lady talking here!. I remember started feeling better by the new year, now feel almost fine. Though I hate yawning still, feeling my ribs streching, ugh!Â  Take your pain meds anyway, but I suggest antidepressants & antianxiety meds & sleeping meds more, cos in my case at least, the more relaxed I felt, I felt it less. It's not easy to bear, but it will pass hopefully.Â  Thinking & praying for you, Ebru

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2017 01:09AM stagefree wrote: Hi Jen I've been reading all the views and doing some thinking the last few months.. as much as have my own plans, my fantasy of having a sudden heart attack to transfer me to my next home is so strong that, my main concern nowadays are to have my legs shaved, no more Brasilian vaxing, it hurt like hell! :)) Have manicure/pedicure with bright nailpolish, have my hair in good condition and have a bit of make up, so that the ones dealing with my body will not be disgusted at basic level. I am serious. I know many pass away in their beds, surrounded by loved ones, yet my hope is something more like having coffee with DH somewhere, when I suddenly (yet calmly-working on that, still trying to prepare myself to it) drop dead. I had the driving car during the attack fantasy for some time, but now that I no longer drive long-distance, Dying on the way to groceystore is not an ascar-winning scene. Anyway, I dread tubes in my body, machines beeping and the hospital smell. But if be it, I'll prefer the most expensive private one for my last breath. I admit I am scared of dying, but lately am curious of what's next as I witness most of my dear friends here having gone before me. There are only a few of my long-term BCO sisters left still alive, so it is somehow becoming easier to accept it coming for me at some point. Ironic. We seek hope mostly on the boards, don't we? I no longer do that. Have read so much, witnessed so much, that now am at another level now, still occasionaly sharing info & experiences with newbies. It's like a child growing to be adult, the longer we stay alive, the more we grow into perception of death. If I didn't have MBC, I'd be running around for my business meetings, planning our next summer holiday and insisting on moving to a much bigger house with 25-year mortgage, I know. I am grateful for all that I have had so far, I am a luck lady for sure. From now on each breath is a bonus point. Well, guess this sums up my view.. love Ebru

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2017 11:59PM stagefree wrote: yes Jen, I sure am getting rid of everything I no longer need and have been rearranging the house for DH & DS for sometime now. Without making them feel it :) I had attended the funeral of my ex boss from years ago, with whom we parted on not very good terms at that time. He was unfair to my performance and I lived professional hell, going through serious office mobbing for almost 2 years after which I quit .. yet, when I heard he suddenly passed away in a home accident ( was young), I went to the funeral, stopd by him and told him, I forgave him. Prayed for him. About a week later, I saw a dream him smiling at me and he thanked. This has been the ultimate example for me to believe the soul doesn't die.. at least no harm in believing so. I have also been trying to be even more kinder to everyone, cos you know, we do break hearts without noticing.. I don't have many people left surrounding me after having retired, so enjoy the silence, cherish the quality time I have with the few who really care for me. I thank God quite a lot each day for having had the chance to realise how lucky I have been so far with tolerable treatment so far and really not plan the next day any more.. go with the flow.. this past week, I have felt like sharing more on the boards, so I do.. I don't really think too deep about anything any more. Tomorrow I'll be meeting MO to sort out the treatment, as TMs skyrockected to 2400+ fingers crossed once again ;) Hugs Ebru
