Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: Well.. By experience, we mostly start with either AIs or chemo and change therapies along the way.. It's no news really.. But I wanted to share my experience, especially my last experience .. Having failed on AIs on the first round after the first kick of chemo right after dx, I'be been on Xeloda as you see on each of my posts.. The last couple of months had been rough, TMs skyrocked, yet my MO waited. She insisted it worked so well at the start and so quickly, maybe it was my ER+ had to be reconsidered.. So I am back on medical menapuse.. Just after the second shot, I am stable :) and still on Xeloda. I admit, it was no fun the last few months but trusting my MO paid off.. Now crossing fingers for more stable ahead.. I am glad she works not only with her protocol knowledge, but also instincts.. If a chemo / AI does not work the first time round, please do not just dump it and work around it. A reminder for the ones who may not know, Xeloda triggered my heart attack the first time I used it, but now on heart pills, everything is fine. Lupron was first used to put me in menapouse and it was used every 3 months.. The hot flashes were so severe. Now on monthly Zoladex, it's much better.. Hope to give hope to some, who may be worrying about their current therapies.. Lastly, my morphine requiring pain subsided! :) I use painkillers much less and am back onmy feet :))))) There are bad days, yes.. But then definitely better ones. I thank BCO & my sisters here who are by my side. Deeply feel it always Love, Ebru Dx 4/9/2012, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 1, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Chemotherapy 4/11/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 8/24/2012 Hormonal Therapy 6/8/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole), Zoladex (goserelin) Chemotherapy 6/8/2016 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 1, 2016 04:08AM stagefree wrote: hi Jen, Great topic indeed. I feel it's like learning to ride a bicycle. You learn how to do it by doing it yourself. As you stated the experiences of your parents differed. .. Yours will be a totally different experience. And of course ours as well.. Death is a natural part of every creature's being. We never questioned how we were born or did we ? We have absolutely no idea how it all started, to be frank. I am talking beyond any belief system btw.. A plant, an animal, a human baby.. How does that happen?? Indeed I thought a lot about the topic, being a philosophy graduate.. And concluded it's only fantastic to experience it yourself. Like the first time you ride the bicycle without anyone else's help. Just yesterday, we watched a Nat Geo documentary on how brain digests all the info it receives via senses and how it really concludes stuff not exactly they are. Wow I thought! So death maybe is the step to the reality.. Anyway, mental preparation comes first I believe. When you are mentally ready, your loved ones wil be as well. I have been telling my son I came gere before him to prepare our house, his toys etc.. So he got the idea it is only realistic and natural I leave our home before him to build the next one. I am glad for the accomplishment as he is just 11. Hope you find your answers soon, Hugs Ebru

My 7 year old son is counting the days of my current chemo cycles and waiting for my hair to grow back. That is his current understanding of the disease. Now that I have some baby hair back, he wants me to take off my scarf when going out. I too have tried to be as open with him like Karen, who was among the helpful sisters on my first communication with my son, thanks Karen by the way. Now I try to cherish each day I get to spend with him, trying not to think far ahead. I guess things will work out somehow when the time times. We all have our loved ones to help us at each step of this crazy adventure, and our board sisters to support & advice on our daily issues. Love & hugs Ebru

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2014 05:45AM stagefree wrote: Oh dear Karen Ä° somehow skipped this. Now Ä° see what Judie meant by her remark on the quote thread, Ä° am sorry you had to endure so much.. Glad the palliative doc is coming today.. Hopefully you will find relief asap!!! Please everyone, not just you Karen, ask for help from anyone & everyone at the hospital. Each doc his/her own specialty.. Some are brave enough to admit one doc cannot know everthing going on in the body.. During my stay at hospital with severe pleural effusions, MO simply referred me to the pulmunologist for draining & talc procedure.. Well my doc cousin's pulmonologist friend jumped in right in time to say wait for a few weeks & see if chemo & breathing exercises (!!!!!!) would help a bit before further procedures.. Glad Ä° listened to her. Right on the 5th day of using Xeloda accompanied by Taxotere infusions, Ä° had an heart attack. Turned out, Ä° had to have consulted with a cardiologist BEFORE any Â treatment whatsoever, ugh!! Glad Ä° am alive still to share my experience. Now under control of daily heart protecting pills, Â Ä° am still on X.Â  Oh and (sorry this is long, but Ä° find it crucial to share as a live example) Ä° was prescribed mood meds by the neurologist at hand when Ä° said Ä° was desperate for sleep & relief were not the right dosages for me & Ä° was using them wrong cos they didn't work! Well, visiting a psychiatrist, not only the dosages of my Lexapro & Xanax were decreased (no mispelling) Ä° learned to use them properly and a few sessions helped wonders.. Btw on all my medical records the classification is palliative already.. As there is no definite cure anyway, they bundled up treatment and palliative here ha ha :)) practical.. Like simplifying the organisation charts in companies.. Less protocol!! Hugs Ebru
Posts.Title: Palliative Care Karen2012 Heidihill

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2014 10:44AM stagefree wrote: Karen, Ä° had visiting friends so just saw your respond. X nausiated me the first round, but we started again, but fully equipped this time.Â  My RO(!) who treated me 20 years back, suggested Ä° use stomach protection regularly(see my point consult with Them all). Ä° have separate morning & night pills people with stomach ulcers use and a syrup Ä° have both morning & night. No nausia this time... And no stomach pain. But beware you cannot use antacids with X. Docs should know the kinds you can use.. All of us using some form of pill treatment (even if just mood meds) should be on stomach protection Ä°N ADDÄ°TÄ°ON to possible nausia treatment if that SE occurs.. Ugh ... Things we learn through experience.Â  Carbs & Protein are more doable with X at times though we are told to juice, eat greens & reds blah blah.. The thing is to keep your stomach full somehow. Wasa crackers with plain yoghurt helps best when Ä° do feel nausiated. And the extra stomach acid is best sucked by (Barb you know this one!!!) roasted chickpeas.. They are sold ready packaged in any Turkish grocery store (maybe try online if not a near one available). Keep them in your bag/pocket and pop one or two regularly during the day.. Not finished.. The empty stomach's (naturally with that much vomitting) recovery is quite fast with juicing raw potatoes.. Seriously.. My DH's & my stomach ulcers caused by too much medication are mostly recovered with it. As the raw starch covers the inner walls of the stomach instantly, the terrible crawling feeling on the floor in pain decreases, please do try it. Not tasting bad either. The thing is you should drink it as soon as you juice it.. Ä°f wait for a few minutes, the stach will cover a wall in the glass instead ;) which proves it's effect on your stomach.. Also helps balancing the possible diahhrea in some cases..Â  You probably know no dairy product with meat protein.. No cheeseburger! No yoghurt with steak.. Should consume dairy products as snacks, alone. Oh and definitely no milk!!! Never!!! Hope you feel relief soon with palliative care, thinking of you dear. Hugs, Ebru

Posts.Content: stagefree wrote: hey gals, I'd developed chemo skin, rashes even pimples and dark spots.. It's already an issue with age, wrinkles & all.. anyway, I by pure chance bought a donkey milk soap, which I saw at the local market. Always curious to try new stuff.. not only it cleared my rashes and pimples on day 5 of taxotere cycle, my face looks younger.. no kidding. It works wonders on black spots on the nose especially, no longer large pores!!!!!!!!!!!!! Too bad this happened when I am 43 with MBC.. And guess what? The label adress is so close to my summer house! Yep! Visited the factory, bought loads of great donkey milk, goat milk, camel milk and sheep milk soaps along with premium quality virgin oil soaps. These guys export to the US, maybe you can see the brand OLIVOS! Goat milk soap makes my body so fresh and soft, I feel happy. DH also approved the product. Anyway, my soap adventure continues with fabulous scents.. Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 05:01PM stagefree wrote: Had it 20 years ago, without any proper antinausia treatment. I was a high school student. Yes I did not have nausia, with proper antinausia meds like Zofran & all, but never felt normal once throughout the 6 month treatment. So glad it is over for now. Red Devil, for me, was way better than the Taxotere Truck for sure.Â
